The patient is a 71-year-old woman with advanced end-stage ischemic cardiomyopathy, severe left ventricular dysfunction, atrial fibrillation, and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and chronic kidney disease (CKD). She presents with increased dyspnea and is being treated with milrinone for acute on chronic decompensated systolic heart failure.

The patient has failed home therapy with torsemide and beta-blockers. She is volume overloaded, as evidenced by elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels, elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), bilateral crackles on lung auscultation, ascites, and lower extremity edema. She is not responding to lasix and metolazone on the floor.

A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) shows worsening mitral regurgitation (MR), which may be causing pulmonary hypertension and subsequent right heart failure. The patient's ejection fraction is estimated to be 15-20%. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and is paced with a bi-ventricular pacemaker.

The patient's coronary arteries show a mid-left anterior descending artery (LAD) bare metal stent placed in the past, with troponin levels of 0.04 and CK-MB negative on presentation. Her baseline creatinine level was 2.3, and it is now 1.5. The etiology of CKD is unclear.
